data.title: Error in gitbash with atom shell command not handling directories with spaces in Windows 10
data.body:
### Description

Attempting to use the `atom .`  command was producing the following error in git bash. Running the atom command in the windows command prompt worked fine but gitbash gives the following error.

![Image](https://cloud.githubusercontent.com/assets/12580197/15162400/8ddc48c4-16b7-11e6-89f4-a030b70eb11f.PNG)
### Solution

I noticed that my user folder "Terrell Big T Vest" was being cut off at just "Terrell". I guess the shell command wasn't dealing with the space in the directory path. The solution that solved this issue just involved adding double quotes around a portion of the pushd command like so. 
#### Previous Code

[Link to specific line of code](https://github.com/atom/atom/blob/f00ac5ca0a4c64f4f1b05c394ec4ecfb70fa59ff/resources/win/atom.sh#L2)

``` sh
pushd $(dirname "$0") > /dev/null
```
#### Solution Code

``` sh
pushd "$(dirname "$0")" > /dev/null
```
### Atom Version

1.7.3
### OS Version

Windows 10 version 1511 (OS build 10586.0)

**Expected behavior:** open folder in atom at directory of bash

**Actual behavior:** gave the error provided above via a screenshot and did not open atom.
### Additional Comments

Again, I tested the original code in the windows command prompt and everything works as expected. The original code also works on windows when the user folder does not contain any spaces.
Hopefully this change can be made to the atom.sh folder to prevent this issue with others who have a user folder that contains spaces.

The system can not find the path specified**. And not as changing the route Many thanks in advance. regards

data.title: New delay/duplication in opening file from sshfs mounted drive
data.body:
Up until recently, I have been able to open and edit files in sshfs-mounted drives without problems. Now, when I try to open a file, Atom does the following:

1) Displays a blank tab for 15+ seconds; the name of the tab is the name of the file I'm trying to open
2) Opens the file in a new tab with all the expected content, but the title of the tab is in italics
3) If I close the tab in (2) or navigate to the tab in (1), I see that the formerly blank tab now displays the content expected.

This is very frustrating.

OS X 10.11.2
Atom 1.7.3

data.title: Filepath/name not visible when creating or renaming a file.
data.body: ### Description When creating a new file or renaming a file in the dialog _Enter the new path for the file_ there is no way of seeing the end of a filename/path when this path is longer than the dialog textbox. ### Steps to Reproduce 1. rename a file with a long path or filename 2. try to modify the end of the filename 3. the cursor goes to the correct place in the text but there is no way to see this visually. **Expected behavior:** [What you expected to happen] The cursor moves within the text and the text becomes visible. **Actual behavior:** [What actually happened] The cursor moves withing the text but the text is not visible on screen in the textbox. ### Versions Atom : 1.7.3 Electron: 0.36.8 Chrome : 47.0.2526.110 Node : 5.1.1 OSX: 10.11.4

data.title: Space invisibles disappear when used for alignment(not indent)
data.body:
### Description

The invisible character for spaces disappears once I enter some text. I can understand this being desirable but only expected it to omit the space invisible char when a single space between text occurred. 

Tab invisibles still render as can be seen in [this bug report](https://github.com/atom/atom/issues/10733), I was confused with the actual code I was looking at wondering if the alignment was tabs/spaces/mixed or some other invisible since space invisibles were not rendering.

Code snippet:

``` HTML
<!DOCTYPE html>
<html lang="en">
<head>
    <style>
        h1 {
            font-size:     
            font-size      test
            font-size:     70px;
            font-size:     
        }
    </style>
<head>
</html>
```

Image:
![invisibles bug](http://i.imgur.com/HIhg9jw.png)

I can verify the same issue with a new JS file `var test =            'space aligned, invisibles don't show'` as well so it's not language specific.
### Steps to Reproduce
1. Create a new file.
2. Note how aligning text with spaces the space invisibles disappear once text occurs. Not the same if tabs are used where they still render.

**Expected behavior:** Invisibles for spaces should still render between text if the length is greater than 1, else an optional render option for this should exist.

**Actual behavior:** Unlike tab invisibles space invisibles disappear.
### Versions

Atom 1.7.3 OSX 10.11.3

data.title: Changed shift-delete to 'editor:delete-line'
data.body:
This should not need explanation, but incase you're wondering or want to discuss...

https://github.com/atom/atom/issues/11717

It makes no sense to have 'ctrl-x': core:cut AND 'shift-DELETE': 'core:cut'.
There is no button bound to 'editor:delete-line' which is an extremely commonly needed action in programming.
core:cut is a very poor replacement for delete-line, because it overwrites the clipboard which may have something useful in it, with something that's useless and the user is trying to discard.

Thus 'shift-delete': 'editor:delete-line' should be the default keybinding in my opinion.

data.title: Default KeyBinding: Shift-Delete should be 'editor:delete-line', not 'core:cut'
data.body:
Atom.oi 1.5.3 default keybindings on Linux

(only relevant keybindings shown)

```
'body':
  'ctrl-x': 'core:cut'
  'shift-delete': 'core:cut'
```

In my opinion this makes NO SENSE. It should be as follows

```
'body':
  'ctrl-x': 'core:cut'
  'shift-delete': 'editor:delete-line'
```

Cut is cut, and delete is delete.

There is no button bound to 'editor:delete-line' which is an extremely commonly needed action in programming.
core:cut is a very poor replacement for delete-line, because it overwrites the clipboard which may have something useful in it, with something that's useless and the user is trying to discard.

data.title: Integer configuration type does not allow the value 0
data.body:
### Description

The `integer` configuration type does not allow the value `0` to be entered.
### Steps to Reproduce
1. Install a package that has an `integer` type configuration setting ([linter-phpcs](https://atom.io/packages/linter-phpcs) for example)
2. Open the settings for the package installed in step 1
3. Attempt to set the setting (eg. Warning Severity) to a value of `0`
4. Note how it instead sets the default value.

**Expected behavior:**

`0` is allowed to be set.

**Actual behavior:**

All integer values other than `0` are allowed, however attempting to set `0` just sets the default value.
### Versions

You can get this information from executing `atom --version` and `apm --version` at the command line. Also, please include the OS and what version of the OS you're running.

OS: Windows 10 Professional x64 (Technical Preview)
Atom: 1.8.0-beta3
apm:

```
apm  1.9.2
npm  2.13.3
node 0.10.40
python 2.7.11
git 2.7.4.windows.1
visual studio 2015
```

Also reported in https://github.com/AtomLinter/linter-phpcs/issues/154 by a user on Win10/Atom v1.7.3.

data.title: File opened from UNC Patch results empty
data.body:
Using Atom 1.7.3 on Windows 10 Version 1511 (Build 10586.218)

I cannot open files on mapped network letter (for example Z: mapped to \server\folder). The folder tree on the left pane correctly shows the files and folders available. But, when I open a file the tab is empty, as with new files. The content in the file does not appear. I have reproduced this behavior with different files and here a gif demostrating the problem:

http://recordit.co/PbyCXTYcsd

Seems a similar issue to this closed one:
https://github.com/atom/atom/issues/2885

data.title: Incorrect selection with tabs
data.body:
### Prerequisites
- [ ] Can you reproduce the problem in [safe mode](http://flight-manual.atom.io/hacking-atom/sections/debugging/#check-if-the-problem-shows-up-in-safe-mode)?
- [x] Are you running the [latest version of Atom](http://flight-manual.atom.io/hacking-atom/sections/debugging/#update-to-the-latest-version)?
- [x] Did you check the [debugging guide](http://flight-manual.atom.io/hacking-atom/sections/debugging/)?
- [x] Did you check the [FAQs on Discuss](https://discuss.atom.io/c/faq)?
- [x] Are you reporting to the [correct repository](https://github.com/atom/atom/blob/master/CONTRIBUTING.md#atom-and-packages)?
- [x] Did you [perform a cursory search](https://github.com/issues?q=is%3Aissue+user%3Aatom+-repo%3Aatom%2Felectron) to see if your bug or enhancement is already reported?
### Description

Occasionally when selecting an area with the cursor, anything with tabs is (visually) incorrectly selected.  This happens randomly so I haven't tried safe mode yet.

![incorrect-tabs-selection](https://cloud.githubusercontent.com/assets/2766036/15095252/8e1fb54c-148b-11e6-94eb-bce8a3cead96.png)
### Steps to Reproduce
1. Select a region of text that has leading tabs
2. Get (un)lucky

**Expected behavior:** The selection to be correct, like so:
![correct-tabs-selection](https://cloud.githubusercontent.com/assets/2766036/15095255/b55695b8-148b-11e6-9e54-d9326efed277.png)

**Actual behavior:** See the first image.
### Versions

You can get this information from executing `atom --version` and `apm --version` at the command line. Also, please include the OS and what version of the OS you're running.

```
Atom    : 1.9.0-dev-02d7bde (Electron 37 branch)
Electron: 0.37.8
Chrome  : 49.0.2623.75
Node    : 5.10.0
```

```
apm  1.10.0
npm  2.13.3
node 0.10.40
python 2.7.10
git 2.7.0.windows.1
visual studio 2015
```

Windows 10 x64.

I can still open a new window from inside the editor, but not from a shell.

data.title: Atom doesn't register as a `public.plain-text` editor on OS X
data.body:
### Prerequisites
- [x] Can you reproduce the problem in [safe mode](http://flight-manual.atom.io/hacking-atom/sections/debugging/#check-if-the-problem-shows-up-in-safe-mode)?

> I haven't actually tested safe mode, because I can't see how it'd be relevant (the problem is determined by Atom, but actually happens outside Atom).
- [X] Are you running the [latest version of Atom](http://flight-manual.atom.io/hacking-atom/sections/debugging/#update-to-the-latest-version)?

> I'm running v1.7.3, which the check updates function reports is the current-latest version.
- [X] Did you check the [debugging guide](http://flight-manual.atom.io/hacking-atom/sections/debugging/)?

> I didn't check the debugging guide because this is about a missing `Info.plist` entry and I can't see how debugging would help.
- [X] Did you check the [FAQs on Discuss](https://discuss.atom.io/c/faq)?

> I found [getting Atom to handle different extensions](https://discuss.atom.io/t/recognizing-different-file-extensions-zmc/27428) and [making Atom recognise a given extension as a particular language](https://discuss.atom.io/t/how-do-i-make-atom-recognize-a-file-with-extension-x-as-language-y/26539) but I don't believe this is an instance of either of those.
- [X] Are you reporting to the [correct repository](https://github.com/atom/atom/blob/master/CONTRIBUTING.md#atom-and-packages)?

> Pretty sure this is the only repository that can control Atom's `Info.plist` file.
- [X] Did you [perform a cursory search](https://github.com/issues?q=is%3Aissue+user%3Aatom+-repo%3Aatom%2Felectron) to see if your bug or enhancement is already reported?

> I searched both open and closed issues for `UTI`, `public.plain-text`, and `"default text editor"` but nothing seemed relevant.

Happy to be corrected about any of this.
### Description

After installing Atom on my Mac, many files (especially those without extensions) still open in (shudder) TextEdit. I took a look in Atom's `Info.plist` file, and also used [duti](http://duti.org/duti.1.html) to check the list of handlers, and it appears that Atom doesn't register for the `public.plain-text` UTI. As a text editor, it really should register with OS X to handle the editing of text files.
### Steps to Reproduce
1. Install Atom v1.7.3 on OS X
2. Open a Terminal window
3. Type `touch MyAtomTestFile` and press return
4. Type `open MyAtomTestFile` and press return

**Expected behavior:** I expected the file to open in Atom

**Actual behavior:** The file opens in TextEdit (or perhaps another editor depending on what you have installed).

(You'll probably also want to `rm MyAtomTestFile`, too.)
### Versions

OS X 10.11.4 (15E65).

`$`**`atom --version`**

```
Atom    : 1.7.3
Electron: 0.36.8
Chrome  : 47.0.2526.110
Node    : 5.1.1
```

`$`**`apm --version`**

```
apm  1.9.2
npm  2.13.3
node 0.10.40
python 2.7.10
git 2.7.4
```

data.title: Atom fails to build on Windows 10
data.body:
### Prerequisites
- [ ] Can you reproduce the problem in [safe mode](http://flight-manual.atom.io/hacking-atom/sections/debugging/#check-if-the-problem-shows-up-in-safe-mode)?
- [X] Are you running the [latest version of Atom](http://flight-manual.atom.io/hacking-atom/sections/debugging/#update-to-the-latest-version)?
- [X] Did you check the [debugging guide](http://flight-manual.atom.io/hacking-atom/sections/debugging/)?
- [X] Did you check the [FAQs on Discuss](https://discuss.atom.io/c/faq)?
- [X] Are you reporting to the [correct repository](https://github.com/atom/atom/blob/master/CONTRIBUTING.md#atom-and-packages)?
- [X] Did you [perform a cursory search](https://github.com/issues?q=is%3Aissue+user%3Aatom+-repo%3Aatom%2Felectron) to see if your bug or enhancement is already reported?

I would like to manage my versions of Atom via building the executables from source, but I've been unable to successfully build anything with script/build.
### Steps to Reproduce
1. Follow the instructions [here](https://github.com/atom/atom/blob/master/docs/build-instructions/windows.md).
2. Navigate to local Atom clone.
3. Check out any version (that I've tried so far).
4. Wait a few minutes for the errors to roll in.

**Actual behavior:**

gyp ERR! cwd D:\github\atom\atom\build\node_modules\minidump

### Versions

    Version 4.6.01038

npm: v3.8.6

data.title: Using Atom to edit commit-messages shouldn't open new window
data.body: If I use Atom as Git's editor as described [here](https://github.com/atom/language-git#git-editing-support-in-atom-), a new window opens when I run `git commit`. It should first check if the containing folder's already been opened and switch to that window. ### Expectation ### Reality

data.title: Atom 1.7.3 crashes on OSX local network drive while saving scss files, erases file
data.body:
Howdy folks, 

While working on an scss file on our company's local network drive, Atom will crash when using cmd + s to save. This issue is a few versions old, but I can always reopen and access the file I was working on and start over from the last save. Now, for the third time, Atom has entirely deleted the file I was working on. The file on the network drive is now blank. Zero bytes. I am on the latest version. I have run it in safe mode. I have uninstalled and reinstalled. 

Anyone else having trouble?

data.title: Retain Position when toggling Soft Wrap
data.body:
### Description

When the user selects **Toggle Soft Wrap**, it will cause the page to reorganize and push them to an earlier point in the list if there are many items of long length. I would expect this instead to enable soft wrapping and keep my position.

I am suggesting that once the document is reformatted for soft wrap, to jump to the user's last known line number to retain their progress.
### Versions

1.7.3

data.title: Meteor.call() crashes
data.body:
### Description

Meteor.call() crashes atom. Safe mode works, but I'm not using any additional packages (fresh install on Windows). Intermitenly starts and stops working (the bug).
### Steps to Reproduce

Type out meteor.call(

**Expected behavior:** [What you expected to happen]
To not crash

**Actual behavior:** [What actually happened]
Crashed
### Versions

Microsoft Windows [Version 6.1.7601]
Atom    : 1.7.3
Electron: 0.36.8
Chrome  : 47.0.2526.110
Node    : 5.1.1

data.title: bug fixes
Using pipes with the atom command in a shell should open a new atom window or tab with the piped output.
data.body:
This would be useful for browsing the output of a long running command in atom.

**Steps which explain the enhancement**
1. Run some command in a terminal which produces a lot of output.
   eg: `ps aux`
2. Pipe the output into atom.
   `ps aux | atom`
3. The output should now appear in atom

**Current and suggested behavior**

Currently doing this opens a new empty window.

I've confirmed that this feature works in Textmate but surprisingly, not in any tty editors.

**Atom Version:** 1.7.3
**OS and Version:** Mac OSX 10.10.5

data.title: Release key keybinding behaviour change proposal
data.body:
I read #11035 and it seems obvious that the option is not received as expected, which made me think that the problem is not the default behaviour, but that it shouldn't be needed to `unset!` the keybindings.

If we have:

```
'body':
  'ctrl-tab': 'pane:show-next-item'
  'ctrl-shift-tab': 'pane:show-previous-item'
```

The [_method_ called](https://github.com/atom/atom/blob/72721af3c63fd0d0bd0b0dd196ff28a3cab9ba11/src/pane.coffee#L347) when `ctrl` is released (`ctrl-tab ^ctrl`) seems to not affect the pane to show at all, it should just change the stack. Yet it changes behaviour of tab switching.

data.title: Consistency within OS X
data.body:
Hi all, just wanted to raise this design flaw - although flaw is a strong word. 

On OS X all of the close tab "X's" are on the left hand side of the tab throughout the OS (Safari, Finder, Terminal..) however in Atom they're on the right! It would be great to have a setting allowing them to be repositioned to the left, allowing for more consistency within OS X.

Many thanks,
